channel.title: Question on my book
channel.description: Now over christmas my grandmother bought me 2 books. Now as I am reading the other one, I take a minute to see whats in the other book, I see "covers java 5.0" now she accidentally bought the wrong one... should I read it or is there a lot changed from 5 to 7?

item.title: Question on my book
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

I learnt with Java 5. Anyway, you’ll get deprecation warnings on compilation.

Read full topic

item.title: Question on my book
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Everyone works differently, but I know it’s not too hard to start with an older version and learn a lot of base Java knowledge, then work with recent java applications and programs to familiarize yourself with Java 7. I’m sure you would be able to manage by doing ti with Java 5, either way, it’s Java.

Read full topic

item.title: Question on my book
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Everything that applies in Java 5 applies in 7. Newer versions generally offer more improvements, and Java 5 is a bit out dated.

Read full topic

item.title: Question on my book
item.dc:creator: @kronixz kronikz
item.description:
@kronixz wrote:

Now over christmas my grandmother bought me 2 books.
Now as I am reading the other one, I take a minute to see whats in the other book, I see “covers java 5.0” now she accidentally bought the wrong one… should I read it or is there a lot changed from 5 to 7?
